responses.content: We’re focused on ensuring that the Watch tab is retentive and valuable before promoting it broadly. Premium, professional content acts as a ‘tent pole’—attracting users who then stay for other content. While we’ve seen good growth and user interest, we’re still in the phase of making it better, rather than heavily monetizing Watch. Over time, Watch could contribute to revenue as we refine the user experience and content offerings.

responses.topic: Facebook App Engagement in the U.S. and Canada
responses.content: The Facebook app had a strong quarter in the U.S. and Canada with improvements across multiple areas. Internationally, video improvements helped engagement, while in the U.S., it was more about core feed engagement. Although we’re highly penetrated in these markets, we saw growth driven by a mix of product enhancements and positive user response.

Current antitrust reviews focus heavily on the Instagram acquisition. Back in 2012, Instagram was one of many emerging mobile camera apps—not a guaranteed success. Its growth since is due to the founders’ talents as well as our investments (infrastructure, ad model, safety systems). Competition remains intense (e.g., Snapchat, built-in OS camera features), and we continue to believe the Instagram acquisition was complementary. We’ll work openly with regulators to address these concerns.

Commerce is a major long-term opportunity. Facebook Marketplace, Instagram Shopping, and WhatsApp payments are all in different stages. Marketplace is already large, while Instagram Shopping is nascent, and WhatsApp payments are testing in India. We’re exploring multiple approaches to payments: building on existing infrastructure (like mobile wallets and integrations) and new technologies (like Libra) to reduce costs and friction. Although Libra is more ambitious, both existing and new rails can drive better commerce experiences.

We believe a federal privacy framework would be beneficial. While GDPR has set principles in Europe, having 50 different U.S. state regulations could be challenging for businesses and competition. We support clear federal rules that protect privacy and maintain a healthy, innovative market environment.

Building VR/AR is taking longer than expected, but our long-term vision remains intact. Oculus Quest is selling well, and we’re investing in both high-quality and smaller-scale content. Although mass-market adoption will take more years, each year of development improves our capabilities, brand, and product quality. We remain optimistic that AR/VR will become mainstream over time.

responses.topic: News Tab and Partnerships with Publishers
responses.content: We launched a dedicated News tab to give people who value high-quality journalism a focused experience. By creating a separate space, we can form sustainable business partnerships with publishers and potentially pay them for curated, high-quality content. While not everyone uses Facebook for news, a meaningful subset will find this valuable. This approach supports journalism and provides a long-term, stable model for funding news content.

Instagram Shopping is at a very early stage. We tested shopping ads in Q3, where users tap an ad, see a product description page, and purchase on the business’s mobile site. With over 90% of Instagram users following at least one business, there’s a huge opportunity. As we reduce friction and help people discover and buy products more easily, we see upside both for consumers and our long-term business growth. But near-term, browsing and discovery still drive the majority of our business.

Stories represent a big area of growth and opportunity. We have over 3 million advertisers using Stories across Facebook, Instagram, and Messenger. Lessons learned from mobile have helped us move advertisers to Stories quickly. We’ve introduced tools like automatic placements and customizable templates to make it easier for advertisers. While Stories currently monetize at lower rates than feed, we believe in the long-term potential of Stories as user behavior continues to shift.

We expect a more pronounced deceleration in Q4 revenue growth due to lapping strong product optimizations made last year—specifically, improvements to the ad auction and increased ad load on Instagram feed and stories. While Q3 didn’t show strong targeting headwinds, we still anticipate regulatory, platform, and product changes leading to signal loss over time.

Ad targeting headwinds are still largely ahead of us. Factors include evolving regulations (e.g., GDPR), platform privacy changes (by operating systems), and our own product changes (like Off-Facebook Activity controls). While these haven’t significantly impacted Q3, we expect them to weigh on growth in Q4 and beyond into 2020.

APAC and Rest of World growth accelerated partly due to product optimizations and unlocking more inventory in lower ARPU markets. Brazil’s macro environment also improved year-over-year, providing easier comps. We expect upcoming Q4 deceleration to be global, as product optimizations from last year impacted all regions.

We plan to accelerate headcount growth in 2020, focusing on privacy, safety, security, core product innovation, and frontier areas like AR/VR. Non-headcount expenses (infrastructure, marketing) will also grow. Significant past CapEx investments flow into depreciation, affecting cost of revenue. Over time, we’ll assess the ROI and may adjust spending levels, but near-term investments remain robust.

Stories impressions are growing rapidly, driving overall supply increases but resulting in lower ad prices due to abundant inventory. Thus, the monetization gap vs. feed ads remains. While advertisers increasingly adopt Stories, price growth lags behind. We expect Stories revenue growth to come more from impression volume than pricing improvements in the near term.

OFA launched in August and we’re gradually expanding it globally. Early reception is positive, but it’s too early to quantify adoption rates or the impact on targeting. As more users opt out of data usage, we anticipate some degree of targeting signal loss, but the timeline and scope remain uncertain.

We have introduced ads in Marketplace and Facebook search results, but search on Facebook is predominantly people-centric queries, not commerce-related. Given this user behavior, search ads remain an immaterial revenue contributor. We’ll continue to explore opportunities, but don’t expect meaningful near-term impact.

questions: Dave, can you clarify the Q4 revenue deceleration drivers and why targeting headwinds weren’t visible in Q3?
Mark/Sheryl, can you provide an update on Instagram Shopping’s progress and strategy as Q4 approaches?
